male_sentence: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after a 2-day history of fever, productive cough, and severe dyspnea. The parents report that the boy had no health problems at birth but developed respiratory problems as an infant that have continued throughout his life, including recurrent pulmonary infections. Vital signs include: temperature of 37.5ºC (99.5ºF), pulse of 105/min, respiratory rate of 34/min, and SpO2 of 87%. Physical examination shows digital clubbing and cyanosis. Chest X-rays show hyperinflation of the lungs and chronic interstitial changes. The boy’s FEV1/FVC ratio is decreased, and his FRC is increased. The resident reviewing his case is studying new gene therapies for this boy’s condition that will reintroduce the gene for which this boy is defective. An important component of this therapy is identifying a vector for the selective introduction of the replacement gene into the human body. Which of the following would be the best vector to provide gene therapy for this boy’s respiratory symptoms?
female_sentence: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents after a 2-day history of fever, productive cough, and severe dyspnea. The parents report that the girl had no health problems at birth but developed respiratory problems as an infant that have continued throughout her life, including recurrent pulmonary infections. Vital signs include: temperature of 37.5ºC (99.5ºF), pulse of 105/min, respiratory rate of 34/min, and SpO2 of 87%. Physical examination shows digital clubbing and cyanosis. Chest X-rays show hyperinflation of the lungs and chronic interstitial changes. The girl’s FEV1/FVC ratio is decreased, and her FRC is increased. The resident reviewing her case is studying new gene therapies for this girl’s condition that will reintroduce the gene for which this girl is defective. An important component of this therapy is identifying a vector for the selective introduction of the replacement gene into the human body. Which of the following would be the best vector to provide gene therapy for this girl’s respiratory symptoms?
options: ['Adenovirus', 'Rhinovirus', 'Human immunodeficiency virus-1', 'Rabies virus', 'Coxsackie A virus']

male_sentence: A 45-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of drainage from his left great toe. He has had an ulcer on his left great toe for over eight months. He noticed increasing drainage from the ulcer over the past week. His past medical history is notable for diabetes mellitus on insulin complicated by peripheral neuropathy and retinopathy. His most recent hemoglobin A1c was 9.4%. He has a 25 pack-year smoking history. He has multiple sexual partners and does not use condoms. His temperature is 100.8°F (38.2°C), blood pressure is 150/70 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination reveals a 1 cm ulcer on the plantar aspect of the left great toe surrounded by an edematous and erythematous ring. Exposed bone can be palpated with a probe. There are multiple small cuts and bruises on both feet. A bone biopsy reveals abundant gram-negative rods that do not ferment lactose. The pathogen most likely responsible for this patient’s current condition is also strongly associated with which of the following conditions?
female_sentence: A 45-year-old female presents to her primary care physician complaining of drainage from her left great toe. She has had an ulcer on her left great toe for over eight months. She noticed increasing drainage from the ulcer over the past week. Her past medical history is notable for diabetes mellitus on insulin complicated by peripheral neuropathy and retinopathy. Her most recent hemoglobin A1c was 9.4%. She has a 25 pack-year smoking history. She has multiple sexual partners and does not use condoms. Her temperature is 100.8°F (38.2°C), blood pressure is 150/70 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination reveals a 1 cm ulcer on the plantar aspect of the left great toe surrounded by an edematous and erythematous ring. Exposed bone can be palpated with a probe. There are multiple small cuts and bruises on both feet. A bone biopsy reveals abundant gram-negative rods that do not ferment lactose. The pathogen most likely responsible for this patient’s current condition is also strongly associated with which of the following conditions?
options: ['Otitis externa', 'Gastroenteritis', 'Waterhouse-Friedrichsen syndrome', 'Rheumatic fever', 'Toxic shock syndrome']

male_sentence: A 47-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of gradually worsening facial and lower extremity swelling. He has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight gain during this time. His blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema and 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. A 24-hour collection of urine shows 4.0 g of proteinuria. Microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen shows thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy shows dense subepithelial deposits. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
female_sentence: A 47-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of gradually worsening facial and lower extremity swelling. She has had a 4-kg (8.8-lb) weight gain during this time. Her blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital edema and 2+ pretibial edema bilaterally. A 24-hour collection of urine shows 4.0 g of proteinuria. Microscopic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen shows thickening of the glomerular basement membrane. Electron microscopy shows dense subepithelial deposits. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
options: ['Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibodies', 'Anti-myeloperoxidase antibodies', 'Anti-streptolysin O antibodies', 'Anti-C3 convertase antibodies', 'Anti-collagen type IV antibodies']

male_sentence:
A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of yellowish discoloration of the skin for 1 day. The discoloration first appeared on his face and then spread to his trunk. There have been no changes in his bowel habits or urination. He was born at 38 weeks’ gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. He is exclusively breastfed every 2–3 hours. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice of the face, chest, and abdomen. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 17.6 g/dL
Reticulocytes 0.3%
Maternal blood group A, Rh-negative
Fetal blood group 0, Rh-positive
Serum
Bilirubin, total 7 mg/dL
Direct 0.6 mg/dL
Free T4 7 μg/dL
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?"
female_sentence:
A 5-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician by her father because of yellowish discoloration of the skin for 1 day. The discoloration first appeared on her face and then spread to her trunk. There have been no changes in her bowel habits or urination. She was born at 38 weeks’ gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She is exclusively breastfed every 2–3 hours. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice of the face, chest, and abdomen. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 17.6 g/dL
Reticulocytes 0.3%
Maternal blood group A, Rh-negative
Fetal blood group 0, Rh-positive
Serum
Bilirubin, total 7 mg/dL
Direct 0.6 mg/dL
Free T4 7 μg/dL
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: ['Congenital hypothyroidism', 'Rhesus incompatibility', 'Dubin-Johnson syndrome', 'Physiological neonatal jaundice', 'Biliary atresia']

male_sentence: A 16-year-old boy presents with a sore throat. The patient says symptoms onset acutely 3 days ago and have progressively worsened. He denies any history of cough, nasal congestion or rhinorrhea. No significant past medical history or current medications. The vital signs include: temperature 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 74/min, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Physical examination is significant for anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. There is edema of the oropharynx and tonsillar swelling but no tonsillar exudate. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
female_sentence: A 16-year-old girl presents with a sore throat. The patient says symptoms onset acutely 3 days ago and have progressively worsened. She denies any history of cough, nasal congestion or rhinorrhea. No significant past medical history or current medications. The vital signs include: temperature 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure 110/70 mm Hg, pulse 74/min, respiratory rate 20/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Physical examination is significant for anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. There is edema of the oropharynx and tonsillar swelling but no tonsillar exudate. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
options: ['Reassurance', 'Rapid strep test', 'Ultrasound of the anterior cervical lymph nodes', 'Empiric treatment with antibiotics', 'Empiric treatment with antivirals']

male_sentence: A 75-year-old man is brought to a physician’s office by his daughter with complaints of diarrhea and vomiting for 1 day. His stool is loose, watery, and yellow-colored, while his vomitus contains partially digested food particles. He denies having blood or mucus in his stools and vomitus. Since the onset of his symptoms, he has not had anything to eat and his daughter adds that he is unable to tolerate fluids. The past medical history is unremarkable and he does not take any medications regularly. The pulse is 115/min, the respiratory rate is 16/min, the blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and the temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). The physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and slightly sunken eyes. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Which of the following physiologic changes in glomerular filtration rate (GFR), renal plasma flow (RPF), and filtration fraction (FF) are expected?
female_sentence: A 75-year-old woman is brought to a physician’s office by her son with complaints of diarrhea and vomiting for 1 day. Her stool is loose, watery, and yellow-colored, while her vomitus contains partially digested food particles. She denies having blood or mucus in her stools and vomitus. Since the onset of her symptoms, she has not had anything to eat and her son adds that she is unable to tolerate fluids. The past medical history is unremarkable and she does not take any medications regularly. The pulse is 115/min, the respiratory rate is 16/min, the blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and the temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F). The physical examination shows dry mucous membranes and slightly sunken eyes. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Which of the following physiologic changes in glomerular filtration rate (GFR), renal plasma flow (RPF), and filtration fraction (FF) are expected?
options: ['Increased GFR, increased RPF, increased FF', 'Decreased GFR, decreased RPF, increased FF', 'Decreased GFR, decreased RPF, no change in FF', 'Decreased GFR, decreased RPF, decreased FF', 'Increased GFR, decreased RPF, increased FF']

male_sentence: A 60-year-old African-American male presents to your office complaining of dysuria, paresthesias, and blurry vision. His body mass index is 37.2 kg/m2. Which of the following drugs would most significantly increase the levels of C-peptide in the blood when administered to this patient?
female_sentence: A 60-year-old African-American female presents to your office complaining of dysuria, paresthesias, and blurry vision. Her body mass index is 37.2 kg/m2. Which of the following drugs would most significantly increase the levels of C-peptide in the blood when administered to this patient?
options: ['Metformin', 'Insulin', 'Glipizide', 'Acarbose', 'NPH']

male_sentence:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of progressive fatigue, abdominal pain, and loss of appetite over the past 3 days. He was treated in the emergency department once in the past year for swelling of his hands and feet. He was adopted as a baby from Sudan and his family history is unknown. He does not take any medication. He is lethargic. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 141/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 68/40 mm Hg. Examination shows pale, dry mucous membranes and scleral icterus. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 7.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 93 fL
Reticulocyte count 11%
Serum
Lactate dehydrogenase 194 IU/L
Total bilirubin 6.4 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.5 mg/dL
Haptoglobin 21 mg/dL (N = 41–165)
Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?"
female_sentence:
A 2-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her father because of progressive fatigue, abdominal pain, and loss of appetite over the past 3 days. She was treated in the emergency department once in the past year for swelling of her hands and feet. She was adopted as a baby from Sudan and her family history is unknown. She does not take any medication. She is lethargic. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 141/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 68/40 mm Hg. Examination shows pale, dry mucous membranes and scleral icterus. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 7.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 93 fL
Reticulocyte count 11%
Serum
Lactate dehydrogenase 194 IU/L
Total bilirubin 6.4 mg/dL
Direct bilirubin 0.5 mg/dL
Haptoglobin 21 mg/dL (N = 41–165)
Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
options: ['Anti-erythrocyte antibodies on Coombs test', 'Pale stool on rectal examination', 'Splenomegaly on ultrasound', 'Hypocellular bone marrow on biopsy', 'Low ferritin level in serum']

male_sentence: A 46-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting approximately 4 hours after a fatty meal. He reports that this has happened before, but this episode is worse. The vomit was non-bilious and did not contain any blood. He recalls frequent episodes of vague epigastric pain that often wakes him up during the night. Over the counter omeprazole and a small meal or snack would provide some relief in the past. The patient also mentions recent anorexia and early satiety. He takes over the counter ibuprofen several times a week for headaches. Blood pressure is 125/82 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respiratory rate is 19/min. On physical examination, he has hypoactive bowel sounds, and his abdomen seems grossly distended and tympanic on percussion. Which of the following is most consistent with a duodenal ulcer?
female_sentence: A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting approximately 4 hours after a fatty meal. She reports that this has happened before, but this episode is worse. The vomit was non-bilious and did not contain any blood. She recalls frequent episodes of vague epigastric pain that often wakes her up during the night. Over the counter omeprazole and a small meal or snack would provide some relief in the past. The patient also mentions recent anorexia and early satiety. She takes over the counter ibuprofen several times a week for headaches. Blood pressure is 125/82 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respiratory rate is 19/min. On physical examination, she has hypoactive bowel sounds, and her abdomen seems grossly distended and tympanic on percussion. Which of the following is most consistent with a duodenal ulcer?
options: ['Non-bilious vomiting', 'Early satiety', 'Ibuprofen use', 'Omeprazole provides relief of the symptoms', 'Food ingestion provides relief of the symptoms']

male_sentence: A 21-year-old man presents to a physician because of extreme fatigue, palpitations, fever, and weight loss. He developed these symptoms gradually over the past 3 months. His blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 109/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). The patient is emaciated and pale. There are conjunctival hemorrhages and several bruises noted in the inner cubital area bilaterally. There are also a few lesions on the left foot. The cardiac examination reveals a holosystolic murmur best heard at the 4th intercostal space at the left sternal edge. Two blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus, and echocardiography shows a tricuspid valve aneurysm. Which of the following would most likely be revealed in a detailed history from this patient?
female_sentence: A 21-year-old woman presents to a physician because of extreme fatigue, palpitations, fever, and weight loss. She developed these symptoms gradually over the past 3 months. Her blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 109/min, respiratory rate is 17/min, and temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F). The patient is emaciated and pale. There are conjunctival hemorrhages and several bruises noted in the inner cubital area bilaterally. There are also a few lesions on the left foot. The cardiac examination reveals a holosystolic murmur best heard at the 4th intercostal space at the left sternal edge. Two blood cultures grew Staphylococcus aureus, and echocardiography shows a tricuspid valve aneurysm. Which of the following would most likely be revealed in a detailed history from this patient?
options: ['Percutaneous nephrostomy for acute ureterolithiasis 5 months ago', 'Lung abscess evacuation 3 months ago', 'Catheterization of the urinary bladder', 'Chronic intravenous drug usage', 'Adenoidectomy 6 months ago']

male_sentence: A 32-year-old man makes an appointment at his physician’s office for a regular health check-up. He does not have any complaints and mentions that he has started to train for an upcoming marathon and hydrates exclusively with electrolyte solutions. He has been trying unsuccessfully to quit smoking for a few years now. He has hypercholesterolemia, which is controlled with a low-cholesterol diet. Family history is significant for hypertension in both of his parents. His mother died of myocardial infarction a few years ago. The vital signs include heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.6 °C (99.68 °F), and blood pressure 120/88 mm Hg. The physical exam findings are within normal limits. A routine electrocardiogram (ECG) is done and is shown below. The abnormal wave seen on the ECG tracing represents which of the following mechanical events?
female_sentence: A 32-year-old woman makes an appointment at her physician’s office for a regular health check-up. She does not have any complaints and mentions that she has started to train for an upcoming marathon and hydrates exclusively with electrolyte solutions. She has been trying unsuccessfully to quit smoking for a few years now. She has hypercholesterolemia, which is controlled with a low-cholesterol diet. Family history is significant for hypertension in both of her parents. Her father died of myocardial infarction a few years ago. The vital signs include heart rate 55/min, respiratory rate 16/min, temperature 37.6 °C (99.68 °F), and blood pressure 120/88 mm Hg. The physical exam findings are within normal limits. A routine electrocardiogram (ECG) is done and is shown below. The abnormal wave seen on the ECG tracing represents which of the following mechanical events?
options: ['Ventricular depolarization', 'Period between ventricular depolarization and repolarization', 'Ventricular repolarization', 'Atrial depolarization', 'Atrial repolarization']

male_sentence: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness while walking his dog. He spontaneously regained consciousness 20 seconds later. He has a history of atrial fibrillation. Current medications include metoprolol. He reports that he forgot to take his medication the day before and took double the dose this morning instead. A decrease in which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's episode?
female_sentence: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after briefly losing consciousness while walking her dog. She spontaneously regained consciousness 20 seconds later. She has a history of atrial fibrillation. Current medications include metoprolol. She reports that she forgot to take her medication the day before and took double the dose this morning instead. A decrease in which of the following most likely contributed to this patient's episode?
options: ['Phosphorylation of myosin light chains in vascular smooth muscle cells', 'Activity of protein kinase C in cardiomyocytes', 'Activity of protein kinase A in vascular smooth muscle cells', 'Activity of adenylyl cyclase in cardiomyocytes', 'Diastolic efflux of calcium in cardiomyocytes']

male_sentence: A 62-year-old man presents to his primary care physician because of abdominal pain that started after he went camping several months ago and drank from a mountain stream. This past year, he also went on a trip around the world, eating local foods at each stop. Furthermore, he has had a history of cholelithiasis and had his gallbladder removed 3 years ago. Otherwise, his medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension and diabetes. Based on clinical suspicion, an endoscopy and biopsy was performed showing a mix of mononuclear cells and a motile, urease-positive, oxidase-positive, spiral shaped organism. The changes seen on biopsy in this patient most likely predispose him to which of the following pathologies?
female_sentence: A 62-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician because of abdominal pain that started after she went camping several months ago and drank from a mountain stream. This past year, she also went on a trip around the world, eating local foods at each stop. Furthermore, she has had a history of cholelithiasis and had her gallbladder removed 3 years ago. Otherwise, her medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension and diabetes. Based on clinical suspicion, an endoscopy and biopsy was performed showing a mix of mononuclear cells and a motile, urease-positive, oxidase-positive, spiral shaped organism. The changes seen on biopsy in this patient most likely predispose her to which of the following pathologies?
options: ['Esophageal adenocarcinoma', 'Gallbladder adenocarcinoma', 'Colon adenocarcinoma', 'MALT lymphoma', 'Pancreatic adenocarcinoma']

male_sentence: A 27-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of progressive numbness and weakness in his left arm and left leg for 2 days. During this period, he has also had urinary urgency and incontinence. Three months ago, he had blurry vision, difficulty distinguishing colors, and headache for one week, all of which have resolved. The patient has smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks four glasses of wine each week. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg. Examination shows 3/5 strength in the left arm and leg, and 5/5 strength on the right side. Upon flexion of the neck, the patient experiences a shooting electric sensation that travels down the spine. MRI of the brain shows gadolinium-enhancing lesions in the right central sulcus, cervical spinal cord, and optic nerve. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
female_sentence: A 27-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of progressive numbness and weakness in her left arm and left leg for 2 days. During this period, she has also had urinary urgency and incontinence. Three months ago, she had blurry vision, difficulty distinguishing colors, and headache for one week, all of which have resolved. The patient has smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years and drinks four glasses of wine each week. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 110/68 mm Hg. Examination shows 3/5 strength in the left arm and leg, and 5/5 strength on the right side. Upon flexion of the neck, the patient experiences a shooting electric sensation that travels down the spine. MRI of the brain shows gadolinium-enhancing lesions in the right central sulcus, cervical spinal cord, and optic nerve. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
options: ['Administer lorazepam', 'Administer IV methylprednisolone', 'Plasmapheresis', 'Administer tissue plasminogen activator', 'Glatiramer acetate therapy']

male_sentence: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of upper abdominal pain and nausea for the past hour. The patient rates the pain as an 8 to 9 on a 10-point scale. He has had an episode of nonbloody vomiting since the pain started. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoporosis. The patient has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He drinks 5–6 alcoholic beverages daily. Current medications include glyburide, lisinopril, and oral vitamin D supplements. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Examination shows severe epigastric tenderness to palpation with guarding but no rebound. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas; no gallstones are visualized. The patient is admitted to the hospital for pain control and intravenous hydration. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient’s pain?
female_sentence: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of upper abdominal pain and nausea for the past hour. The patient rates the pain as an 8 to 9 on a 10-point scale. She has had an episode of nonbloody vomiting since the pain started. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and osteoporosis. The patient has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 40 years. She drinks 5–6 alcoholic beverages daily. Current medications include glyburide, lisinopril, and oral vitamin D supplements. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg. Examination shows severe epigastric tenderness to palpation with guarding but no rebound. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows diffuse enlargement of the pancreas; no gallstones are visualized. The patient is admitted to the hospital for pain control and intravenous hydration. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient’s pain?
options: ['Patient-controlled intravenous hydromorphone', 'Transdermal bupivacaine on request', 'Oral acetaminophen every 6 hours', 'Oral gabapentin every 24 hours', 'Transdermal fentanyl every 72 hours']

male_sentence: A previously healthy 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of fever, irritability, and rash for 3 days. The rash started around the mouth before spreading to the trunk and extremities. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash with flaccid bullae on the neck, flexural creases, and buttocks. Gentle pressure across the trunk with a gloved finger creates a blister. Oropharyngeal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these skin findings?
female_sentence: A previously healthy 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of fever, irritability, and rash for 3 days. The rash started around the mouth before spreading to the trunk and extremities. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash with flaccid bullae on the neck, flexural creases, and buttocks. Gentle pressure across the trunk with a gloved finger creates a blister. Oropharyngeal examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of these skin findings?
options: ['Toxin-induced cleavage of desmoglein', 'Bacterial production of erythrogenic toxin', 'Bacterial invasion of the epidermis', 'Autoantibody deposition in stratum spinosum', 'Autoantibody binding of hemidesmosomes']

male_sentence: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother with fever and difficulty breathing after receiving the BCG vaccine. He has never had a reaction to a vaccine before. He has a history of 2 salmonella infections over the past 2 years. He was born at 35 weeks’ gestation and spent one day in the neonatal intensive care unit. His parents' family histories are unremarkable. His temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 80/55 mmHg, pulse is 135/min, and respirations are 24/min. On examination, he appears acutely ill. He has increased work of breathing with intercostal retractions. A petechial rash is noted on his trunk and extremities. A serological analysis in this patient would most likely reveal decreased levels of which of the following cytokines?
female_sentence: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room by her father with fever and difficulty breathing after receiving the BCG vaccine. She has never had a reaction to a vaccine before. She has a history of 2 salmonella infections over the past 2 years. She was born at 35 weeks’ gestation and spent one day in the neonatal intensive care unit. Her parents' family histories are unremarkable. Her temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 80/55 mmHg, pulse is 135/min, and respirations are 24/min. On examination, she appears acutely ill. She has increased work of breathing with intercostal retractions. A petechial rash is noted on her trunk and extremities. A serological analysis in this patient would most likely reveal decreased levels of which of the following cytokines?
options: ['Interferon alpha', 'Interferon gamma', 'Interleukin 1', 'Interleukin 12', 'Tumor necrosis factor alpha']

male_sentence: A 4-year-old boy with a history of cerebral palsy is brought to the neurology clinic by his mother with progressive tightness in the lower extremities. Although the patient has been intermittently undergoing physiotherapy for the past 2 years at a specialized center, the patient’s mother is concerned he cannot yet climb the stairs. The neurologist recommends a different treatment, which involves multiple intramuscular injections of a drug in the muscles of the lower extremities to relieve tightness. The neurologist says this treatment approach is also often used to relieve headaches and reduce facial wrinkles. Which of the following is most likely the mechanism of action of this drug?
female_sentence: A 4-year-old girl with a history of cerebral palsy is brought to the neurology clinic by her father with progressive tightness in the lower extremities. Although the patient has been intermittently undergoing physiotherapy for the past 2 years at a specialized center, the patient’s father is concerned she cannot yet climb the stairs. The neurologist recommends a different treatment, which involves multiple intramuscular injections of a drug in the muscles of the lower extremities to relieve tightness. The neurologist says this treatment approach is also often used to relieve headaches and reduce facial wrinkles. Which of the following is most likely the mechanism of action of this drug?
options: ['Acts as a superantigen', 'Stimulates adenylate cyclase', 'Reduces neurotransmitter GABA', 'Blocks the release of acetylcholine', 'Interferes with the 60s ribosomal subunit']

male_sentence: A 37-year-old African American man is brought to the emergency department by police. The patient refused to leave a petting zoo after closing. He states that he has unique ideas to revolutionize the petting zoo experience. The patient has a past medical history of multiple suicide attempts. His temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's cardiac and pulmonary exams are within normal limits. He denies any nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, or systemic symptoms. The patient struggles to answer questions, as he is constantly changing the subject and speaking at a very rapid rate. The patient is kept in the emergency department overnight and is observed to not sleep and is very talkative with the nurses. Which of the following is the best long-term therapy for this patient?
female_sentence: A 37-year-old African American woman is brought to the emergency department by police. The patient refused to leave a petting zoo after closing. She states that she has unique ideas to revolutionize the petting zoo experience. The patient has a past medical history of multiple suicide attempts. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's cardiac and pulmonary exams are within normal limits. She denies any nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, or systemic symptoms. The patient struggles to answer questions, as she is constantly changing the subject and speaking at a very rapid rate. The patient is kept in the emergency department overnight and is observed to not sleep and is very talkative with the nurses. Which of the following is the best long-term therapy for this patient?
options: ['Lithium', 'Valproic acid', 'Risperidone', 'Haloperidol', 'Diphenhydramine']

male_sentence: A previously healthy 9-year-old, Caucasian boy presents to your office with severe abdominal pain. His father also mentions that he has been urinating significantly less lately. History from the father reveals that the boy suffers from acne vulgaris, mild scoliosis, and had a bout of diarrhea 3 days ago after a family barbecue. Lab work is done and is notable for a platelet count of 97,000 with a normal PT and PTT. The young boy appears dehydrated, yet his serum electrolyte levels are normal. What is the most likely etiology of this boy's urinary symptoms?
female_sentence: A previously healthy 9-year-old, Caucasian girl presents to your office with severe abdominal pain. Her mother also mentions that she has been urinating significantly less lately. male_sentence: A 6-month-old boy has a weak cry, poor suck, ptosis, and constipation. His condition began 2 days ago with a single episode of abundant watery stool and elevated temperature. The infant was exclusively breastfed till 5 months of age, after which he began receiving grated potatoes, pumpkin, carrots, and apples, in addition to the breastfeeding. He does not receive any fluids other than breast milk. The last new food item to be introduced was homemade honey that his father added several times to grated sour apples as a sweetener 2 weeks before the onset of symptoms. The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 70/40 mm Hg, heart rate 98/min, respiratory rate 29/min, and temperature 36.4°C (98.2°F). On physical examination, he is lethargic and has poor head control. Which of the following options is a part of the pathogenesis underlying the patient’s condition?

male_sentence: A 44-year-old man presents to his primary care physician due to a tremor. options: ['Autoimmune destruction of the adrenal gland', '↓ adrenocorticotropic hormone secretion from the pituitary gland', '↓ corticotropin-releasing hormone secretion from the hypothalamus', 'Prolonged corticosteroid therapy', '↑ iron absorption and deposition in the body']

male_sentence:
A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellow discoloration of his eyes and skin for 2 days. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation and weighed 3066 g (6 lb 12 oz); he now weighs 3200 g (7 lb 1 oz). He is exclusively breastfed. His older sister died 3 months after liver surgery. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 145/min, and respirations are 40/min. Examination shows yellow discoloration extending to the palms and soles. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:
Hematocrit 51%
Serum
Bilirubin
Total 16.1 mg/dL
Direct 0.7 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 22 U/L
AST 12 U/L
ALT 12 U/L
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

male_sentence: A 13-year-old boy is brought to a physician with severe fevers and headaches for 3 days. The pain is constant and mainly behind the eyes. He has myalgias, nausea, vomiting, and a rash for one day. Last week, during an academic winter break, he traveled on a tour with his family to several countries, including Brazil, Panama, and Peru. They spent many evenings outdoors without any protection against insect bites. There is no history of contact with pets, serious illness, or use of medications. The temperature is 40.0℃ (104.0℉); the pulse is 110/min; the respiratory rate is 18/min, and the blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. A maculopapular rash is seen over the trunk and extremities. Several tender lymph nodes are palpated in the neck on both sides. A peripheral blood smear shows no organisms. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?

options: ['Babesiosis', 'Chagas disease', 'Dengue fever', 'Malaria', 'Zika virus']

male_sentence: A 34-year-old male comes to his family physician with complaints of joint pain that has been present for over 7 weeks. Prior to the onset of his arthritis, he recalls having a gastrointestinal infection which caused mild diarrhea and abdominal cramps. He recovered well and had no issues until his joint pain started. A prescription for naproxen was previously prescribed but he still does not feel well. He has no significant past medical or family history. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg, respirations are 17/min, pulse is 64/min, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). Which of the following therapies is likely to be most beneficial in treating this patient’s condition?
female_sentence: A 34-year-old female comes to her family physician with complaints of joint pain that has been present for over 7 weeks. options: ['Diclofenac', 'Sulfasalazine', 'Methotrexate', 'Ketoprofen', 'Ceftriaxone']

male_sentence: Five days after admission into the ICU for drug-induced acute kidney injury, a 27-year-old man develops fever. He is currently on a ventilator and sedatives. Hemodialysis is performed via a catheter placed in the right internal jugular vein. Feeding is via a nasogastric tube. An indwelling urinary catheter shows minimum output. His blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg, the pulse is 112/min, the respirations are 32/min, and the temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F). The examination of the central catheter shows erythema around the insertion site with no discharge. Lung auscultation shows rhonchi. Cardiac examination shows no new findings. A chest CT scan shows bilateral pleural effusions with no lung infiltration. Empirical antibiotic therapy is initiated. Blood cultures obtained from peripheral blood and the catheter tip show S. aureus with a similar antibiogram. Urinary culture obtained from the indwelling catheter shows polymicrobial growth. Which of the following best explains this patient’s recent findings?
female_sentence: Five days after admission into the ICU for drug-induced acute kidney injury, a 27-year-old woman develops fever. She is currently on a ventilator and sedatives. Hemodialysis is performed via a catheter placed in the right internal jugular vein. Feeding is via a nasogastric tube. An indwelling urinary catheter shows minimum output. Her blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg, the pulse is 112/min, the respirations are 32/min, and the temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F). options: ['Catheter-associated urinary tract infection', 'Central catheter-related bacteremia', 'Endocarditis', 'Naso-gastric tube sinusitis', 'Ventilator-associated pneumonia']

male_sentence: Six days after undergoing a left hemicolectomy for colorectal carcinoma, a 59-year-old man collapses in the hospital hallway and is unconscious for 30 seconds. Afterwards, he complains of shortness of breath and chest pain with deep inhalation. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years but quit prior to admission to the hospital. He does not drink alcohol. He is in distress and appears ill. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, and pulse is 135/min and weak. Oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Physical examination shows elevated jugular venous distention. Cardiac examination shows a regular, rapid heart rate and a holosystolic murmur that increases during inspiration. His abdomen is soft and mildly tender to palpation around the surgical site. Examination of his extremities shows pitting edema of the left leg. His skin is cold and clammy. Further examination is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?

Examination of her extremities shows pitting edema of the left leg. Her skin is cold and clammy. Further examination is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
options: ['Rapid, aberrant contractions of the atria', 'Stenosis of the carotid arteries', 'Dilated right ventricular cavity', 'Anechoic space between pericardium and epicardium', 'Reduced regional ventricular wall motion']

male_sentence: A 30-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents. He has burns over his left hand. The mother tells the doctor that the child was playing unobserved in the kitchen and accidentally grabbed a hot spoon, which produced the burn. She also says his pediatrician had expressed concern as to the possibility of autism spectrum disorder during the last visit and had suggested regular follow-up. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. On physical examination, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse rate is 140/min, and respiratory rate is 28/min. He is irritable and crying excessively. On examination, the skin of the left hand is white-pink with small blisters over the entire dorsal aspect of the hand, but the skin of the palmar surface is undamaged. There is a sharp demarcation between healthy skin above the wrist and the injured skin of the hand. There are no burns or another injury anywhere else on the child. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the burns?
female_sentence: A 30-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents. She has burns over her left hand. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the burns?
options: ['Forced immersion in hot water', 'Burn as a result of poor supervision', 'Cigarette burns', 'Accidental burns', 'Abusive burn from a hot spoon']

male_sentence: A father brings in his 7-year-old twin sons because they have a diffuse rash. They have several papules, vesicles, pustules, and crusts on their scalps, torso, and limbs. The skin lesions are pruritic. Other than that, the boys appear to be well. The father reports that several children in school have a similar rash. The family recently returned from a beach vacation but have not traveled internationally. Both boys have stable vital signs within normal limits. What is the most common complication of the infection the boys appear to have?

What is the most common complication of the infection the girls appear to have?
options: ['Hepatitis', 'Bacterial superinfection of skin lesions', 'Pneumonia', 'Encephalitis', 'Cerebellar ataxia']

male_sentence: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of progressive dysphagia. He initially had symptoms only when consuming solid foods, but for the past 2 months he has also had difficulty swallowing liquids. He describes a feeling of food “getting stuck” in his throat. He was diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease 2 years ago and has had episodic pallor of his fingers since adolescence. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 24 years. His only medication is omeprazole. His pulse is 65/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 127/73 mm Hg. Examination shows thickening of the skin of his fingers, with small white papules on his fingertips. There are small dilated blood vessels on his face, lips, and tongue. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's dysphagia?

options: ['Uncoordinated contractions of the esophagus', 'Protrusion of thin tissue membranes into the esophagus', 'Esophageal smooth muscle atrophy and fibrosis', 'Degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons', 'Outpouching of the lower pharyngeal mucosa and submucosa\n"']

male_sentence: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for joint pain following the acute onset of a diffuse, pruritic rash for the past 24 hours. A week ago, he was diagnosed with pharyngitis after returning home from summer camp and is currently taking antibiotics. There is no family history of serious illness. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital edema, generalized lymphadenopathy, and well-circumscribed, erythematous, confluent skin lesions of variable sizes up to several centimeters in width over his entire body. There is pain on passive movement of wrists and ankle joints bilaterally. Urine dipstick shows 1+ proteinuria. There is no hematuria. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
female_sentence: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for joint pain following the acute onset of a diffuse, pruritic rash for the past 24 hours. He also reports that he has had 4 episodes of watery diarrhea per day for the last 3 days. He has chronic bronchitis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F) and pulse is 65/min. Examination shows diffuse crackles over the left lower lung field. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.8 g/dL
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Platelet count 150,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 131 mEq/L
Cl- 102 mEq/L
K+ 4.7 mEq/L
An x-ray of the chest shows consolidation of the left lower lobe. A Gram stain of induced sputum shows numerous neutrophils but no organisms. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

male_sentence: A 9-year-old boy from Eritrea is admitted to the hospital for lethargy and increased work of breathing. He has had recurrent episodes of fever, shortness of breath, and fatigue in the past 3 years. His pulse is 132/min and blood pressure is 90/66 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Auscultation of the chest shows coarse crackles in both lungs and a diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex. Despite appropriate lifesaving measures, he dies. A photomicrograph of a section of myocardium obtained at autopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's cardiac disease?
female_sentence: A 9-year-old girl from Eritrea is admitted to the hospital for lethargy and increased work of breathing. options: ['Amastigote infiltration', 'Beta-myosin heavy chain defect', 'Non-caseating granulomatous inflammation', 'Type II hypersensitivity reaction', 'Exotoxin-mediated myonecrosis']

male_sentence: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with symptoms of heat intolerance, unintentional weight loss, feelings of anxiety, and excessive energy that hinder him from falling asleep at night. On physical exam, the patient is found to have mildly protuberant eyes bilaterally as well as discoloration and swelling of his shins. Which of the following lab results would most likely be present in this patient?
female_sentence: A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with symptoms of heat intolerance, unintentional weight loss, feelings of anxiety, and excessive energy that hinder her from falling asleep at night. On physical exam, the patient is found to have mildly protuberant eyes bilaterally as well as discoloration and swelling of her shins. Which of the following lab results would most likely be present in this patient?
options: ['Decreased anti-TSH antibodies', 'Decreased free T4', 'Decreased serum TSH', 'Increased anti-mitochondrial antibodies', 'Increased serum TSH']

male_sentence: A 72-year-old man with a medical history significant for chronic kidney disease stage 4, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, presents to the office for a scheduled visit. During his last visit, the physician started discussing with him the possibility of starting him on dialysis for his chronic kidney disease. The patient has no complaints about his health and enjoys spending time with his family. At presentation, he is afebrile; the blood pressure is 139/89 mm Hg and the heart rate is 80/min. On physical examination, his pulses are bounding, the complexion is pale, he has a grade ⅙ holosystolic murmur, breath sounds remain clear, and 2+ pedal edema to the knee. The measurement of which of the following laboratory values is most appropriate to screen for renal osteodystrophy in this patient?
female_sentence: A 72-year-old woman with a medical history significant for chronic kidney disease stage 4, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus, presents to the office for a scheduled visit. options: ['Erythrocyte sedimentation rate', 'Serum C-reactive protein level', 'Serum intact parathyroid hormone level', 'Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level', 'Serum vitamin B-12 level']

male_sentence: An 8-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with puffy eyes. The patient’s parents noticed that his eyes were very puffy this morning thus prompting his presentation. They state their son has always been very healthy and other than a rash acquired from wrestling treated with a topical antibiotic has been very healthy. His temperature is 98.3°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, pulse is 89/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam is notable for periorbital edema but is otherwise unremarkable. Urinalysis is notable for red blood cells and an amber urine sample. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
female_sentence: An 8-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with puffy eyes. The patient’s parents noticed that her eyes were very puffy this morning thus prompting her presentation. They state their daughter has always been very healthy and other than a rash acquired from wrestling treated with a topical antibiotic has been very healthy. male_sentence: A one-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother, who recently immigrated to the United States and does not have health insurance. He was born at home, and has not received any medical care since birth. The mother states the boy has become irritable and has been feeding poorly. In the last day, she said he seems "stiff" and is having apparent muscle spasms. On your exam, you note the findings in figure A. Which of the following interventions might have prevented this disease?

options: ['Conjugated polysaccharide vaccine given to infant at birth', 'Toxoid vaccine given to mother pre-natally', 'Vitamin injection given to newborn at birth', 'Improved maternal nutrition', 'Genetic counseling']

male_sentence:
A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of diffuse bone pain in his right leg. His family immigrated to the United States 6 months ago from northern Canada. He is below the 5th percentile for height and at the 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the right distal femur. There is hepatosplenomegaly. male_sentence: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after he was found down by his son. male_sentence: A 58-year-old department store manager comes to his doctor’s office complaining that he had recently been waking up in the middle of the night with abdominal pain. male_sentence:
