female_sentence: A 70-year-old woman with hyperlipidemia and hypertension returns to her cardiologist for ongoing blood pressure management. She reports feeling fine with no trouble with her medications. She exercises regularly and sleeps well without snoring or daytime somnolence. Her blood pressure measurements in the past have ranged from 160 - 170/80 - 100 mmHg. Today, her pressure is 150/100 mmHg with a pulse of 65/min while on hydrochlorothiazide and ramipril. Physical exam reveals a II/VI early systolic murmur with split S2 is appreciated at the right upper sternal border. There is unremarkable carotid, renal, or abdominal bruits. What is the most common cause of her hypertension?
options: ['Primary hyperaldosteronism', 'Hypothyroidism', 'Stiffening of the aorta', 'Obstructive sleep apnea', 'Aortic stenosis']

male_sentence: A 73-year-old man is brought to the physician by his son for evaluation of impaired memory and word-finding difficulties for 2 years. He was recently asked to step down from his position as volunteer accountant for a local charity organization because he was no longer able to coordinate his tasks. He reports that he has become unable to taste or smell his food. Two years later, the patient dies. At autopsy, examination of the brain shows generalized cortical atrophy. A photomicrograph of a section of the brain is shown. The inclusions indicated by the arrows are predominantly composed of which of the following substances?
female_sentence: A 73-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for evaluation of impaired memory and word-finding difficulties for 2 years. She was recently asked to step down from her position as volunteer accountant for a local charity organization because she was no longer able to coordinate her tasks. She reports that she has become unable to taste or smell her food. Two years later, the patient dies. At autopsy, examination of the brain shows generalized cortical atrophy. A photomicrograph of a section of the brain is shown. The inclusions indicated by the arrows are predominantly composed of which of the following substances?
options: ['Alpha-synuclein', 'Viral ribonuclear proteins', 'Amyloid-β', 'Hyperphosphorylated tau', 'Prion protein']

male_sentence: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe left upper quadrant pain (duration 3 hours, stabbing quality, 10/10 on the pain scale). Past medical history is significant for sickle cell anemia. Physical examination is significant for severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant. Significant splenomegaly is also noted. The patient is admitted to the hospital for close observation and placed on deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis as part of a routine protocol. Laboratory findings drawn sometime after admission demonstrate a normal prothrombin time (PT) and elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT). Which of the following factors is most directly affected by the DVT prophylaxis?
female_sentence: A 40-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe left upper quadrant pain (duration 3 hours, stabbing quality, 10/10 on the pain scale). Past medical history is significant for sickle cell anemia. Physical examination is significant for severe tenderness to palpation in the left upper quadrant. Significant splenomegaly is also noted. The patient is admitted to the hospital for close observation and placed on deep vein thrombosis (DVT) prophylaxis as part of a routine protocol. Laboratory findings drawn sometime after admission demonstrate a normal prothrombin time (PT) and elevated partial thromboplastin time (PTT). Which of the following factors is most directly affected by the DVT prophylaxis?
options: ['VII', 'XIIa', 'VIIa', 'X', 'XII']

male_sentence: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department for a cough and fatigue. The patient was brought in from a nursing home with documentation stating that he has seemed confused for the past day according to the staff. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension. He is currently taking insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. His temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals crackles on pulmonary exam and S4 on cardiac auscultation. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
female_sentence: A 66-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for a cough and fatigue. The patient was brought in from a nursing home with documentation stating that she has seemed confused for the past day according to the staff. The patient has a past medical history of diabetes and hypertension. She is currently taking insulin, metformin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 102°F (38.9°C), blood pressure is 107/58 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals crackles on pulmonary exam and S4 on cardiac auscultation. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
options: ['Azithromycin and admission to the medical floor', 'Azithromycin and discharge', 'Azithromycin, moxifloxacin, and admission to the intensive care unit', 'Ceftriaxone, azithromycin, and admission to the intensive care unit', 'Moxifloxacin and admission to the medical floor']

male_sentence: A 72-year-old man in a nursing home was brought to the emergency department with right hand and leg weakness for 1 hour. There has been a gradual increase in the degree of weakness. The patient is disoriented. The medical history includes ischemic heart disease diagnosed 2 months ago, and long histories of diabetes and hypertension (30 and 25 years, respectively). On examination, the reflexes are hypertonic and the Babinski reflex is positive. The CT scan is shown. What is the most likely pathologic change?
female_sentence: A 72-year-old woman in a nursing home was brought to the emergency department with right hand and leg weakness for 1 hour. There has been a gradual increase in the degree of weakness. The patient is disoriented. The medical history includes ischemic heart disease diagnosed 2 months ago, and long histories of diabetes and hypertension (30 and 25 years, respectively). On examination, the reflexes are hypertonic and the Babinski reflex is positive. The CT scan is shown. What is the most likely pathologic change?
options: ['Gangrenous necrosis', 'Liquefactive necrosis', 'Caseous necrosis', 'Fibrinoid necrosis', 'Coagulative necrosis']

male_sentence: An 11-year-old boy was brought in by his mother with red tender bumps on his legs. The patient’s mother says that his symptoms started 3 days ago with a low-grade fever, malaise, and joint pain. He began to improve over the next 2 days, but this morning, when he woke up, she noticed multiple painful red bumps on his shins. Past medical history is significant for a recent severe sore throat and fever 1 week ago which resolved without treatment. The vital signs include: temperature 38.0°C (100.4°F), blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg, pulse 85/min, and respiratory rate 15/min. Physical examination reveals multiple, firm and tender erythematous nodules with indistinct borders, averaging 4 cm in diameter. Lesions are localized to the anterior surface of the lower legs. No evidence of drainage, bleeding, abscess formation or ulceration. Which of the following is the next best diagnostic step in this patient?
female_sentence: An 11-year-old girl was brought in by her father with red tender bumps on her legs. The patient’s father says that her symptoms started 3 days ago with a low-grade fever, malaise, and joint pain. She began to improve over the next 2 days, but this morning, when she woke up, he noticed multiple painful red bumps on her shins. Past medical history is significant for a recent severe sore throat and fever 1 week ago which resolved without treatment. The vital signs include: temperature 38.0°C (100.4°F), blood pressure 120/70 mm Hg, pulse 85/min, and respiratory rate 15/min. Physical examination reveals multiple, firm and tender erythematous nodules with indistinct borders, averaging 4 cm in diameter. Lesions are localized to the anterior surface of the lower legs. No evidence of drainage, bleeding, abscess formation or ulceration. Which of the following is the next best diagnostic step in this patient?
options: ['Throat culture', 'Chest radiograph', 'p-ANCA serology', 'Bone marrow biopsy', 'Colonoscopy']

male_sentence:
A 54-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of fatigue. He reports that he recently went on a vacation to South America with his family but just wanted to stay in his hotel all day due to fatigue. His past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. He takes lovastatin and lisinopril. He drinks socially and has a 20 pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min. On exam, the patient is appropriately interactive and in no acute distress. Mild splenomegaly is noted. Laboratory analysis reveals the following:

Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 36%
Leukocyte count: 3,800/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 140,000/mm^3

A bone marrow aspiration is ordered but after multiple attempts, they are unable to obtain an adequate bone marrow sample. A peripheral blood smear would likely reveal cells that stain with which of the following stains?
female_sentence:
A 54-year-old female presents to her primary care physician complaining of fatigue. She reports that she recently went on a vacation to South America with her family but just wanted to stay in her hotel all day due to fatigue. Her past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia and hypertension. She takes lovastatin and lisinopril. She drinks socially and has a 20 pack-year smoking history. Her temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 16/min. On exam, the patient is appropriately interactive and in no acute distress. Mild splenomegaly is noted. Laboratory analysis reveals the following:

Hemoglobin: 11.0 g/dL
Hematocrit: 36%
Leukocyte count: 3,800/mm^3 with normal differential
Platelet count: 140,000/mm^3

A bone marrow aspiration is ordered but after multiple attempts, they are unable to obtain an adequate bone marrow sample. A peripheral blood smear would likely reveal cells that stain with which of the following stains?
options: ['Prussian Blue', 'Ziehl-Neelsen', 'Periodic acid-Schiff', 'Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase', 'Giemsa']

male_sentence: While on a teaching sabbatical in Uruguay, a pathologist examined the excised liver of an 18-year-old otherwise healthy male who passed away due to massive hepatic necrosis 5 days after he underwent general anesthesia to repair a fractured femur. Which of the following is a general anesthetic most likely responsible for his death?
female_sentence: While on a teaching sabbatical in Uruguay, a pathologist examined the excised liver of an 18-year-old otherwise healthy female who passed away due to massive hepatic necrosis 5 days after she underwent general anesthesia to repair a fractured femur. Which of the following is a general anesthetic most likely responsible for her death?
options: ['Bupivacaine', 'Lidocaine', 'Midazolam', 'Halothane', 'Desflurane']

male_sentence: A 45-year-old man with hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue, lethargy, and epigastric pain after eating. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. Laboratory studies show decreased serum hemoglobin levels and increased serum gastrin levels. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows inflammation of the gastric body and fundus. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen taken from the gastric antrum is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
female_sentence: A 45-year-old woman with hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue, lethargy, and epigastric pain after eating. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. Laboratory studies show decreased serum hemoglobin levels and increased serum gastrin levels. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows inflammation of the gastric body and fundus. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen taken from the gastric antrum is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
options: ['Mucosal cell hyperplasia', 'Enterochromaffin-like cell hyperplasia', 'Parietal cell destruction', 'Chief cell destruction', 'I cell destruction']

male_sentence: A 72-year-old anthropologist with long-standing hypertension visits your office for a routine exam. You notice an abnormality on his laboratory results caused by his regimen of captopril and triamterene. What abnormality did you most likely find?
female_sentence: A 72-year-old anthropologist with long-standing hypertension visits your office for a routine exam. You notice an abnormality on her laboratory results caused by her regimen of captopril and triamterene. What abnormality did you most likely find?
options: ['Hypercalcemia', 'Hyperkalemia', 'Hypernatremia', 'Thrombocytopenia', 'Anemia']

male_sentence: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of lightheadedness, intermittent headaches, and easy bruising. Five months ago, he was treated for an episode of thrombophlebitis. Physical examination shows multiple bruises on his limbs. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 900,000/mm3 and elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase and uric acid. Treatment with a medication is begun that is also used in the treatment of sickle cell disease. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the beneficial effect of this drug in sickle cell disease?
female_sentence: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of lightheadedness, intermittent headaches, and easy bruising. Five months ago, she was treated for an episode of thrombophlebitis. Physical examination shows multiple bruises on her limbs. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 900,000/mm3 and elevated levels of serum lactate dehydrogenase and uric acid. Treatment with a medication is begun that is also used in the treatment of sickle cell disease. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the beneficial effect of this drug in sickle cell disease?
options: ['Inhibition of thrombocyte aggregation', 'Increase in circulating fetal hemoglobin', 'Substitution of cofactors for DNA synthesis', 'Inhibition of stem cell differentiation', "Restoration of the body's iron stores"]

male_sentence: Candida is injected into the skin of a 38-year-old male patient. Forty-eight hours later, there is a 14 mm raised, slightly hardened area at the injection site. What type of hypersensitivity reaction has occurred and what cell type plays a role?
female_sentence: Candida is injected into the skin of a 38-year-old female patient. Forty-eight hours later, there is a 14 mm raised, slightly hardened area at the injection site. What type of hypersensitivity reaction has occurred and what cell type plays a role?
options: ['Type I hypersensitivty; eosinophils', 'Type IV hypersensitivity; mast cells', 'Type III hypersensitivity; CD4+ T cells', 'Type IV hypersensitivity; CD4+ T cells', 'Type I hypersensitivity; macrophages']

male_sentence: A 20-year-old male college student presents to the emergency room at 4 AM in the morning with complaints of abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 hours. He was studying for his exams last night when he became hungry and ate some food from the afternoon after heating it for a while. He says that his symptoms began an hour after he ate the food. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. A physical examination is within normal limits except for signs of dehydration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
female_sentence: A 20-year-old female college student presents to the emergency room at 4 AM in the morning with complaints of abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea for the past 2 hours. She was studying for her exams last night when she became hungry and ate some food from the afternoon after heating it for a while. She says that her symptoms began an hour after she ate the food. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 15/min, pulse is 106/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. A physical examination is within normal limits except for signs of dehydration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: ['Cryptosporidiosis', 'C. difficile colitis', 'Bacillus cereus infection', 'Norovirus infection', 'Rotavirus infection']

male_sentence: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of increasing weakness and numbness of the upper extremities for 5 days. During the past 2 days, he has had urinary incontinence not related to sneezing or laughing. Last summer, he had weakness and numbness of his right lower extremity that was worse when he was outside; he regained his strength 3 weeks later. He has no history of serious illness. He has had 10 female sexual partners in his lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an impaired tandem gait. There is mild spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in both upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. The abdominal reflex is absent. Muscle strength in the right lower extremity is mildly decreased. Sensation to vibration and fine touch is decreased over the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
female_sentence: A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of increasing weakness and numbness of the upper extremities for 5 days. During the past 2 days, she has had urinary incontinence not related to sneezing or laughing. Last summer, she had weakness and numbness of her right lower extremity that was worse when she was outside; she regained her strength 3 weeks later. She has no history of serious illness. She has had 10 male sexual partners in her lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an impaired tandem gait. There is mild spasticity and muscle strength is decreased in both upper extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 4+ bilaterally. The abdominal reflex is absent. Muscle strength in the right lower extremity is mildly decreased. Sensation to vibration and fine touch is decreased over the upper extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
options: ['Antinuclear antibody testing', 'Muscle biopsy', 'Rapid plasma reagin test', 'MRI of the brain and spine', 'Lumbar puncture']

male_sentence: A 37-year-old man presents to your office with heartburn. Following an extensive workup, you diagnose him with a duodenal ulcer secondary to H. pylori infection. You prescribe triple therapy of omeprazole, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of omeprazole?
female_sentence: A 37-year-old woman presents to your office with heartburn. Following an extensive workup, you diagnose her with a duodenal ulcer secondary to H. pylori infection. You prescribe triple therapy of omeprazole, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of omeprazole?
options: ['SST2 receptor agonist', 'Parasympathetic inhibition', 'Reversible block of H2 receptors', 'Inhibition of primary active transport', 'Inhibition of 50S ribosomal subunit']

male_sentence: A 47-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain, discoloration, and swelling of his right hand. Two days ago, he was camping outdoors in Texas with his two young children. He was awoken in the middle of the night by “something crawling on my hand.” The following morning, he saw a wound on his hand that was initially painless, but over the next several hours he noticed reddening and blistering. Yesterday, the lesion turned blue with a blackish discoloration at the center. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bluish plaque with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of erythema at the dorsum of the right hand. Which of the following animals is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
female_sentence: A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain, discoloration, and swelling of her right hand. Two days ago, she was camping outdoors in Texas with her two young children. She was awoken in the middle of the night by “something crawling on my hand.” The following morning, she saw a wound on her hand that was initially painless, but over the next several hours she noticed reddening and blistering. Yesterday, the lesion turned blue with a blackish discoloration at the center. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bluish plaque with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of erythema at the dorsum of the right hand. Which of the following animals is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
options: ['Bald-faced hornet', 'Diamondback rattlesnake', 'Brown recluse spider', 'Striped bark scorpion', 'Deer tick']

male_sentence: Two weeks after starting chemotherapy with etoposide, a 66-year-old man with small cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of persistent nausea and vomiting. His symptoms improve significantly after the administration of metoclopramide. This patient's symptoms were most likely due to the effect of chemotherapy on which of the following structures?
female_sentence: Two weeks after starting chemotherapy with etoposide, a 66-year-old woman with small cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of persistent nausea and vomiting. Her symptoms improve significantly after the administration of metoclopramide. This patient's symptoms were most likely due to the effect of chemotherapy on which of the following structures?
options: ['Vestibular nerve', 'Intestinal smooth muscle', 'Vagus nerve', 'Cerebral cortex', 'Area postrema']

male_sentence: A 55-year-old construction worker is struck by a high-voltage power line while on duty. According to bystanders, the cable struck him on his right arm, after which the man slumped to the ground with his arms and legs shaking. In the emergency department, the man is alert but in severe pain localizing bilaterally in the flanks as well as in his right arm where contact with the power line occurred. A 6 cm burn is present on the right arm. His vitals are within normal limits except for mild tachypnea at 21/min. Which of the following diagnostic tests should be conducted first to evaluate this patient?
female_sentence: A 55-year-old construction worker is struck by a high-voltage power line while on duty. According to bystanders, the cable struck her on her right arm, after which the woman slumped to the ground with her arms and legs shaking. In the emergency department, the woman is alert but in severe pain localizing bilaterally in the flanks as well as in her right arm where contact with the power line occurred. A 6 cm burn is present on the right arm. Her vitals are within normal limits except for mild tachypnea at 21/min. Which of the following diagnostic tests should be conducted first to evaluate this patient?
options: ['FAST ultrasound assessment', 'Urine dipstick', 'Urinalysis', 'X-ray of the arm and shoulder', 'EEG']

male_sentence: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police after he was found undressing himself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as he suspects that his care team is spying on him. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol. When the patient is able to be examined, he is somnolent and non-responsive. His temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate his extremities due to rigidity. His mucous membranes are dry. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
female_sentence: A 22-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by police after she was found undressing herself outside in 110°F weather. The patient refuses to answer any questions as she suspects that her care team is spying on her. The patient recently started college and has presented to the emergency department once before for polysubstance intoxication. The patient attempts to assault a nurse, is restrained, and given diphenhydramine and haloperidol. When the patient is able to be examined, she is somnolent and non-responsive. Her temperature is 104°F (40°C), blood pressure is 147/98 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. She does not comply with any commands, and it is not possible to freely manipulate her extremities due to rigidity. Her mucous membranes are dry. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: ['Catatonic schizophrenia', 'Heat stroke', 'Malignant hyperthermia', 'Neuroleptic malignant syndrome', 'Oversedation']

male_sentence: An 18-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician because his mother is concerned about his walking. The boy was born at 37 weeks’ gestation and spent 1 night in the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory distress. He otherwise has been healthy and started walking independently at 12 months. However, his mother reports that he has stopped walking and appears weaker than he was a few months ago. He also has started having brief convulsive episodes over the past week. His parents are both healthy with no medical conditions. On exam, the child demonstrates muscle rigidity and diffuse muscle wasting. He is unable to stand or sit up straight. His patellar, Achilles, and brachioradialis reflexes are absent. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. A urine sample demonstrates metachromic granules. This patient’s condition is caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?
female_sentence: An 18-month-old girl is brought to her pediatrician because her father is concerned about her walking. The girl was born at 37 weeks’ gestation and spent 1 night in the neonatal intensive care unit for respiratory distress. She otherwise has been healthy and started walking independently at 12 months. However, her father reports that she has stopped walking and appears weaker than she was a few months ago. She also has started having brief convulsive episodes over the past week. Her parents are both healthy with no medical conditions. On exam, the child demonstrates muscle rigidity and diffuse muscle wasting. She is unable to stand or sit up straight. Her patellar, Achilles, and brachioradialis reflexes are absent. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable. A urine sample demonstrates metachromic granules. This patient’s condition is caused by a defect in which of the following enzymes?
options: ['Alpha-galactosidase A', 'Arylsulfatase A', 'Beta-galactocerebrosidase', 'Beta-glucocerebrosidase', 'Hexosaminidase A']

male_sentence: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of a pigmented lesion on his left foot. He has had decreased appetite and a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months. Physical examination shows that on the left medial ankle there is a 2-cm reddish-black nodule with a verrucous surface. A full-thickness excisional biopsy of the lesion shows S100-protein-positive epithelioid cells. A subsequent CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows metastases to the liver; a diagnosis of metastatic melanoma is made. Chemotherapy with aldesleukin is initiated. Which of the following is the mechanism of action for this drug?
female_sentence: A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a pigmented lesion on her left foot. She has had decreased appetite and a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months. Physical examination shows that on the left medial ankle there is a 2-cm reddish-black nodule with a verrucous surface. A full-thickness excisional biopsy of the lesion shows S100-protein-positive epithelioid cells. A subsequent CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows metastases to the liver; a diagnosis of metastatic melanoma is made. Chemotherapy with aldesleukin is initiated. Which of the following is the mechanism of action for this drug?
options: ['Stimulating release of acute-phase reactants', 'Stimulating antigen-processing cells', 'Inhibiting expression of MHC II and Th1 cytokines', 'Activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells', 'Supporting growth of bone marrow stem cells']

male_sentence: A 58-year-old male presents with an acutely elevated blood pressure of 220/140 mmHg. The patient complains of a headache and chest pain, and he has been vomiting for the last several hours. Physical exam demonstrates papilledema and a depressed level of consciousness. To treat this patient's hypertensive emergency, he is started on an IV medication commonly used in this situation. The agent exerts its effect by releasing nitric oxide as a metabolite, which subsequently activates guanylate cyclase and increases production of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle. Which of the following clinical effects would be expected from administration of this medication?
female_sentence: A 58-year-old female presents with an acutely elevated blood pressure of 220/140 mmHg. The patient complains of a headache and chest pain, and she has been vomiting for the last several hours. Physical exam demonstrates papilledema and a depressed level of consciousness. To treat this patient's hypertensive emergency, she is started on an IV medication commonly used in this situation. The agent exerts its effect by releasing nitric oxide as a metabolite, which subsequently activates guanylate cyclase and increases production of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle. Which of the following clinical effects would be expected from administration of this medication?
options: ['Decreased cardiac contractility', 'Increased left ventricular end-diastolic pressure', 'Decreased stroke volume', 'Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure', 'Increased systemic vascular resistance']

male_sentence: A 25-year-old man presents generalized abdominal pain and vomiting for the past hour. He has also had watery diarrhea for several days with no blood or pus in the stools. He is taking an over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medication, which he cannot remember the name of, and drinking oral rehydration solution, which has helped a little. His past medical history shows he was hospitalized 10 years ago for an appendectomy and 4 years ago for a fractured ulna following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs are pulse is 104/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 14/min with shallow breathing, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). On physical examination, pupils are constricted. Extremities are pale and cold. The abdomen is soft but mildly, diffusely tender to palpation with a palpable bladder. No rebound or guarding. Fingerstick blood glucose is 124 mg/dL. Laboratory tests are pending. A urinary catheter is placed, and intravenous fluids are started. Abdominal imaging shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
female_sentence: A 25-year-old woman presents generalized abdominal pain and vomiting for the past hour. She has also had watery diarrhea for several days with no blood or pus in the stools. She is taking an over-the-counter anti-diarrheal medication, which she cannot remember the name of, and drinking oral rehydration solution, which has helped a little. Her past medical history shows she was hospitalized 10 years ago for an appendectomy and 4 years ago for a fractured ulna following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs are pulse is 104/min, blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, respiratory rate of 14/min with shallow breathing, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). On physical examination, pupils are constricted. Extremities are pale and cold. The abdomen is soft but mildly, diffusely tender to palpation with a palpable bladder. No rebound or guarding. Fingerstick blood glucose is 124 mg/dL. Laboratory tests are pending. A urinary catheter is placed, and intravenous fluids are started. Abdominal imaging shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
options: ['Administer naloxone', 'Administer opioid analgesics', 'Scopolamine patch', 'Start dextrose infusion', 'Perform a gastric lavage']

male_sentence: A 26-year-old man with no significant past medical history presents to the ED following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs on presentation are T 99.0 F, BP 100/60 mmHg, HR 125 bpm, RR 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air. He complains of extreme abdominal pain worse in the left upper quadrant which has worsened over the past 30 minutes. Exam demonstrates abdominal wall rigidity, involuntary guarding, and tenderness on light percussion. Bedside sonography shows evidence for hemoperitoneum. Despite administering more intravenous fluids, repeat vitals are T 98.9 F, BP 82/50 mm hg, HR 180 bpm, RR 20/min, SpO2 97% on room air. Which of the following is the best next step?
female_sentence: A 26-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the ED following a motor vehicle accident. Vital signs on presentation are T 99.0 F, BP 100/60 mmHg, HR 125 bpm, RR 16/min, SpO2 98% on room air. She complains of extreme abdominal pain worse in the left upper quadrant which has worsened over the past 30 minutes. Exam demonstrates abdominal wall rigidity, involuntary guarding, and tenderness on light percussion. Bedside sonography shows evidence for hemoperitoneum. Despite administering more intravenous fluids, repeat vitals are T 98.9 F, BP 82/50 mm hg, HR 180 bpm, RR 20/min, SpO2 97% on room air. Which of the following is the best next step?
options: ['Normal saline bolus and re-evaluation of hemodynamics after infusion', 'CT abdomen and pelvis', 'Morphine', 'Abdominal plain film', 'Exploratory laparotomy']

male_sentence: An 80-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fatigue and lightheadedness. He does not have chest pain, palpitations, or difficulty breathing. He has a history of hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, osteoarthritis, and asthma. Current medications include simvastatin, metformin, lisinopril, albuterol, and ibuprofen. His pulse is 48/min and blood pressure is 89/50 mm Hg. He responds slowly to questions but is oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. His lungs are clear to auscultation and bowel sounds are positive with no pulsatile masses or bruits. Pedal pulses are nonpalpable, distal extremities are cold, and capillary refill time is 4 seconds. An ECG shows left axis deviation, a Q wave in lead III, a constant PR interval of 0.15 seconds with every third P wave that is nonconducted, and a QRS interval of .09 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: ['Dopamine', 'Dobutamine', 'Norepinephrine', 'Cardiac pacing', 'Epinephrine']

male_sentence: An 18-year-old male presents to the emergency department trauma bay with a gunshot wound to the abdomen. The patient undergoes an exploratory laparotomy, during which, it is discovered that his splenic artery was damaged at its origin from the celiac trunk. The surgeon ligates the splenic artery at its origin. Which of the following arteries will now be hypoperfused as a result?

options: ['Left gastric artery', 'Gastroduodenal artery', 'Right gastroepiploic artery', 'Left gastroepiploic artery', 'Common hepatic artery']

male_sentence: A 64-year-old man with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary incontinence. The urge to urinate occurs suddenly, and he often is unable to make it to the bathroom before leaking urine. He has no incontinence with coughing or laughing. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography shows a normal post-void residual volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's incontinence?
female_sentence: A 64-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary incontinence. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient's incontinence?
options: ['Doxazosin', 'Midodrine', 'Rivastigmine', 'Mirtazapine', 'Tolterodine']

male_sentence: A 42-year-old man with a history of depression and headaches presents to the emergency room with severe, pulsating pain around the crown of his head beginning 12 hours ago. He last took ibuprofen 2 hours ago but did not feel any improvement in the pain. He has been nauseous and unable to get out of bed and is currently laying in the dark with the lights off. His depression has improved, and he has stopped taking his sertraline 2 months ago. Other than ibuprofen as needed, he is not currently taking any additional medications. Which of the following would be the best treatment for his acute symptoms?

options: ['No treatment necessary', '100% oxygen', 'Propranolol', 'Sumatriptan', 'Amitriptyline']

male_sentence: A 17-year-old high school student was in shop class when he accidentally sawed off his pointer finger while making a bird house. He fainted when he realized his finger had been cut off. The teacher immediately transported the patient to the emergency department and he arrived within 20 minutes. He has a past medical history of asthma, and his only medication is an albuterol inhaler. The patient's current blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg. Analgesics are administered. The teacher states that he left the amputated finger in the classroom, but that the principal would be transporting it to the hospital. Which of the following is the correct method of transporting the amputated finger?

male_sentence: A patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his head. He states that the pain started 1 hour ago after rugby practice. Typically, he takes a special medication for bad headaches, but this time he took 2 doses and noticed no improvement in his symptoms. The patient's current medications that he can recall include sumatriptan and naproxen. He has been admitted to the hospital several times recently for panic attacks and suicide attempts. His temperature is 99.2°F (37.3°C), blood pressure is 129/65 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is given dihydroergotamine, IV fluids, and is started on 100% oxygen. Two hours later, the patient demonstrates slurring of his speech. On physical exam there is drooping of the left side of his mouth, and his left upper extremity demonstrates 2/5 strength. A head CT is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current presentation?

options: ['Hemorrhagic stroke', 'Ischemic stroke secondary to a thrombus', 'Medication reaction', 'Psychogenic symptoms', 'Subarachnoid hemorrhage']

male_sentence: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine urological examination and to refill his birth control pills. His last pap smear at age 22 showed no intraepithelial lesions nor malignancy of the cervical cells. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 days. His last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. He is sexually active with one female partner. His father died of colon cancer at the age of 75 years and his mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 40 years. He mentions that he is planning a backpacking trip through Europe in 2 months. His routine immunizations are all up-to-date. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.5°F) and his blood pressure is 94/58 mm Hg. Pelvic and speculum examination show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the best recommendation for the patient at this time?
female_sentence: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine gynecological examination and to refill her birth control pills. options: ['Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis screening', 'Beta-hCG urine test', 'Repeat Pap smear', 'Mammography', 'No further testing is necessary']

male_sentence: An academic obstetrician is conducting a retrospective cohort study that evaluates the risk of placenta accreta at all statewide medical centers. Per chart review he finds that a prior cesarian birth is associated with a statistically significant increased risk of placenta accreta. The relative risk associated with this finding is 1.23. The associated p-value is 0.03. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the reported association in the context of the study?
female_sentence: An academic obstetrician is conducting a retrospective cohort study that evaluates the risk of placenta accreta at all statewide medical centers. Per chart review she finds that a prior cesarian birth is associated with a statistically significant increased risk of placenta accreta. The relative risk associated with this finding is 1.23. The associated p-value is 0.03. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the reported association in the context of the study?
options: ['The 99% confidence interval includes the null hypothesis.', 'The chance of bias in favor of the alternative hypothesis is 3%.', 'The p-value represents the likelihood of seeing an increased risk of placenta accreta in women with prior cesarian birth, assuming the alternative hypothesis is true.', 'There is a 23% probability of seeing the reported risk by chance alone.', 'The p-value represents the likelihood that the alternative hypothesis is false.']

male_sentence: A 55-year-old man presents with complaints of exertional dyspnea and dry cough. He reports using extra pillows at night to sleep and two nighttime awakenings to catch his breath in the last month. male_sentence: A 22-year-old man presents to the medical clinic after getting bit in the hand by a stray dog 2 days ago. The patient has no past medical history and takes no prescription medications. male_sentence: A 37-year-old man presents to the clinic with pain and swelling of his legs. He states that he first noticed the swelling 6 weeks ago. Initially, the swelling was minimal, but now he is finding it difficult to walk and he can’t fit into any of his shoes. His medical history is significant for systemic lupus erythematosus. He takes ibuprofen and hydroxychloroquine. His temperature is 99°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 153/86 mmHg, and pulse is 88 beats/min. Pitting edema to bilateral knees is noted on physical examination. Urinalysis reveals proteinuria. The patient is started on an immunosuppressant. Two days later the patient returns to clinic complaining of blood in his urine. A urinalysis reveals moderate erythrocytes but is negative for leukocyte esterase, nitrites, or crystals. Diffuse oozing of the bladder mucosa with neovascularization is seen on cystoscopy. Which of the following could have prevented the patient’s condition?

options: ['Ifosfamide', 'Mesna', 'Methotrexate', 'Nitrofurantoin', 'Prednisone']

male_sentence: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother after she found him somnolent at home next to multiple open pill bottles. The boy had seemingly opened several different pill bottles that were in a cabinet in his parent’s bathroom. male_sentence: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for evaluation of progressively worsening swelling around the eyes. He has no history of major medical illness. He had a sore throat and cough 2 weeks ago that resolved spontaneously. Physical examination shows moderate periorbital edema and 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities bilaterally. male_sentence: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of intermittent chest pain and palpitations. He also complains of dyspnea on exertion and has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months despite normal appetite. He has no history of serious medical illness. Cardiac examination shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and a grade 3/6, low pitched, rumbling, mid-diastolic murmur heard best over the apex. Diffuse wheezing and bilateral rales are present in the lung bases. A transthoracic echocardiogram shows a left-ventricular ejection fraction of 40% and a mass in the left atrium. A biopsy of the mass is likely to show which of the following?
female_sentence: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent chest pain and palpitations. male_sentence: A 52-year-old man presents with a complaint of headache for the past 10 days. His headache is diffuse, dull in character, moderate in intensity, and is worse in the morning. It is not associated with fever and sensitivity to light or sound. He experiences occasional nausea but no vomiting. He did not have similar headaches in the past. His blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg; pulse, 60/min, and body mass index is 33.5 kg/m2. The neurological examination reveals normal extraocular movements. Mild bilateral papilledema is present. Which of the following types of cancer has the highest tendency to cause this brain lesion?

options: ['Breast cancer', 'Lung cancer', 'Melanoma', 'Multiple myeloma', 'Thyroid cancer']

male_sentence: A 27-year-old graduate student is bitten by a coral snake while he was hiking alone through the woods and dies 2 hours later from respiratory failure. His body was discovered 7 hours later by a group of campers who promptly called the police. On arrival, the police found his body to be cold and stiff. Which of the following processes is responsible for the rigidity observed?
female_sentence: A 27-year-old graduate student is bitten by a coral snake while she was hiking alone through the woods and dies 2 hours later from respiratory failure. Her body was discovered 7 hours later by a group of campers who promptly called the police. On arrival, the police found her body to be cold and stiff. Which of the following processes is responsible for the rigidity observed?
options: ['Activation of muscle contraction by neurotoxins', 'Reduced affinity of myosin head for actin filament', 'Effect of low temperature on muscle proteins', 'Inhibition of cross-bridge cycling', 'Depletion of intracellular calcium']

male_sentence: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a sudden loss of consciousness. He has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. His mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is somnolent and diaphoretic. Serum studies show a glucose concentration of 22 mg/dL and a potassium concentration of 2.4 mEq/L. A dextrose infusion is administered, after which his glucose concentration normalizes and his symptoms improve. He is admitted to the hospital for further observation. Overnight, he has another episode of decreased consciousness. Serum studies taken during the episode show a glucose concentration of 19 mg/dL, an insulin concentration of 108 mIU/L (N=2.6–24.9), and a C-peptide concentration of 0.3 ng/mL (N = 0.8–3.1). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
female_sentence: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her father because of a sudden loss of consciousness. She has asthma and has been hospitalized multiple times. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: ['Malingering', 'Glucagonoma', 'Primary adrenal insufficiency', 'Conversion disorder', 'Factitious disorder imposed on another\n"']

male_sentence: A 65-year-old male patient comes to the physician’s office for his annual check-up. male_sentence: A 6-month-old boy presents to a pediatrician for the evaluation of recurrent bacterial infections. He has a history of a variety of bacterial infections since birth. Physical examination reveals light-colored skin with silver-colored hair. The pediatrician suspects an immunodeficiency disorder and decides to order several tests. male_sentence: A 48-year-old man with type II diabetes mellitus complicated by peripheral neuropathy presents to the emergency department for a foot wound that he noticed. He denies any pain, fevers, or chills. His temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 150/80 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, and respirations are 22/min. An ulcer with associated erythema and purulence is noted on his foot. Based on his radiography, he is diagnosed with osteomyelitis and admitted to the hospital for partial amputation of his right foot. He is given appropriate prophylaxis for tetanus and discharged 5 hospital days later on antibiotics. He returns to the emergency department one week later with difficulty breathing. His temperature is 98°F (37°C), blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respirations are 27/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. His amputated foot stump is erythematous and edematous but not tender to palpation. An electrocardiogram reveals sinus tachycardia. He requests something to help calm his breathing down. What is the next best step in management?

male_sentence: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of sudden severe pain in his right great toe. Arthrocentesis yields cloudy fluid with a leukocyte count of 18,500/mm3 (80% segmented neutrophils). Polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid is shown. male_sentence: A 74-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after falling down several stairs. He is a known alcoholic. He was started on IV fluids and received a head CT, which was negative. It was decided that he would be watched for one day before being discharged, after a negative work-up. Suddenly, he is unable to move his arms and legs in addition to experiencing difficulty chewing, swallowing, moving his face, and speaking. male_sentence: A previously healthy 67-year-old man comes to the physician for routine health maintenance evaluation. He works at a community center and volunteers at a local homeless shelter. male_sentence: A 66-year-old male with a history of myocardial infarction presents to your primary care office with complaints of dyspnea on exertion and swollen feet and ankles. male_sentence: A 67-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a follow up appointment. male_sentence: A 59-year-old man complains of chest pain that has been present for 4 hours on the 5th day of hospitalization for acute myocardial infarction. 5 days ago, he had a burning sensation in his chest and discomfort in his left shoulder. male_sentence: A 16-year-old boy comes to the emergency department because of left wrist pain and swelling for 5 hours. He fell on an outstretched hand while playing basketball. male_sentence: A 46-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of yellowish discoloration of his eyes, generalized fatigue, and pruritus. male_sentence: A 67-year-old man presents with feelings of nervousness and anxiety. He has also been experiencing back and neck pain with increased muscle tension in these areas. male_sentence: A 72-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a 6-month history of shortness of breath. male_sentence:

He has had knee osteoarthritis for several years and takes occasional acetaminophen for pain control. His diet is full of vegetables. He exercises every day. He has no history of smoking. He had a brother who died at the age of 84 due to hematologic malignancy. The temperature is 36.8℃ (98.2℉), and the blood pressure is 125/85 mm Hg. Hemoglobin 15 g/dL
Leukocyte count 58,000/mm3
Platelet count 250,000/mm3

options: ['DNA hydrolysis', 'Disulfide bond cleavage', 'Endothelin-1 antagonism', 'Osmotic hydration of airway lumen', 'Reduction in airway surface tension']

male_sentence:
A 47-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by paramedics. He was found unconscious on a park bench by a bystander. His history is unobtainable. Vitals include a pulse of 64/min, a respiratory rate of 7/min, and a blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is unresponsive to voice and touch but shows a flexor response to pain. His breathing is shallow. The pupils are constricted, and a response to light cannot be determined. An arterial blood gas sample reveals:
pH 7.26
Pco2 70 mm Hg
HCO3-  26 mEq/L
Which of the following could explain this patient's presentation?
female_sentence:

HCO3-  26 mEq/L
Which of the following could explain this patient's presentation?
options: ['COPD exacerbation', 'Diabetic ketoacidosis', 'Diuretic overdose', 'Hyperventilation', 'Opioid overdose']

male_sentence: A 72-year-old man with a 40 pack-year history of smoking presents to your office with jaundice. After a thorough workup, you determine that the patient has pancreatic cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial statement to inform the patient of his condition?
female_sentence: A 72-year-old woman with a 40 pack-year history of smoking presents to your office with jaundice. After a thorough workup, you determine that the patient has pancreatic cancer. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial statement to inform the patient of her condition?

male_sentence: A 40-year-old man is referred to an optometrist. He complains of mild vision impairment over the last 6 months. His vision has continued to slowly deteriorate and his condition is now affecting his night driving. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled schizophrenia. He takes a low-potency typical antipsychotics and a multivitamin every day. He has been compliant with his medication and has regular follow-up visits. What is the best first step in the management of this patient’s symptoms?
female_sentence: A 40-year-old woman is referred to an optometrist. She complains of mild vision impairment over the last 6 months. Her vision has continued to slowly deteriorate and her condition is now affecting her night driving. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled schizophrenia. What is the best first step in the management of this patient’s symptoms?
options: ['Decrease medication dosage', 'Reassurance', 'Ocular examination under anesthesia', 'Refer to ophthalmologist', 'Slit-lamp examination']

male_sentence: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. He has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens his diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. He takes lisinopril for hypertension. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
female_sentence: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
options: ['Proximal muscle wasting', 'Achlorhydria', 'Adrenal medullary mass', 'Multiple peptic ulcers', 'Pulmonic valve stenosis']

male_sentence: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of painful ulcers in his mouth. Over the past 2 months, he has had increasing fatigue and difficulties concentrating. He has a history of rheumatoid arthritis and was started on a new medication 4 months ago. Examination shows pallor of the mucosal membranes and three tender ulcerative lesions in his mouth. His hemoglobin concentration is 8.7 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 109 μm3. A blood smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
female_sentence: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of painful ulcers in her mouth. options: ['Deficient heme synthesis', 'Deficient DNA crosslink repair', 'Deficient erythropoietin secretion', 'Deficient nitrogenous base production', 'Deficient β-globin chains']

male_sentence: A 70-year-old hypertensive and hyperlipidemic man comes to the emergency department with chief complaints of acute onset of impaired speech and comprehension with a right-sided weakness for the last 1.5 hours. The patient was on 2 antihypertensive medications and a statin, but he was not receiving any antiplatelet drugs. He has a blood pressure of 136/94, heart rate of 84/min, and respiratory rate of 15/min. Initial examination shows global aphasia, right homonymous hemianopia, and hemisensory loss. An acute ischemic stroke caused by distal left internal carotid artery occlusion with salvageable penumbral tissue is diagnosed based on a non-contrast CT scan, brain MRI, and catheter cerebral angiogram. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator is given as treatment within 3 hours of presentation. Which of the following cellular processes is typical of the section of reversible injury noted in this patient?
female_sentence: A 70-year-old hypertensive and hyperlipidemic woman comes to the emergency department with chief complaints of acute onset of impaired speech and comprehension with a right-sided weakness for the last 1.5 hours. The patient was on 2 antihypertensive medications and a statin, but she was not receiving any antiplatelet drugs. Intravenous tissue plasminogen activator is given as treatment within 3 hours of presentation. Which of the following cellular processes is typical of the section of reversible injury noted in this patient?
options: ['Mitochondrial permeability', 'Caspase activation', 'Lysosomal rupture', 'Severe membrane damage', 'Decreased ATP']

male_sentence: A 46-year-old man presents with worsening pain in multiple joints for the past 2 weeks. He says the pain is most severe in the proximal parts of his fingers and his wrists, but it has now spread to his elbows, and, occasionally, his knees. He says the joint involvement is symmetric. He also complains of morning joint stiffness that improves with activity and reports feeling fatigued during the day. He started taking ibuprofen 2 months ago for the pain which initially subsided, but, over the last few weeks, it has worsened despite the medication. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 1 year ago and has had difficulty controlling his blood glucose levels. The patient denies any smoking history, alcohol, or recreational drug use. A review of systems is significant for a weight loss of 3.0 kg (6.6 lb) over the last 3 months despite no change in diet or activity level. Which of the following is the most likely 1st-line medication in this patient?
female_sentence: A 46-year-old woman presents with worsening pain in multiple joints for the past 2 weeks. She says the pain is most severe in the proximal parts of her fingers and her wrists, but it has now spread to her elbows, and, occasionally, her knees. She says the joint involvement is symmetric. She also complains of morning joint stiffness that improves with activity and reports feeling fatigued during the day. She started taking ibuprofen 2 months ago for the pain which initially subsided, but, over the last few weeks, it has worsened despite the medication. Which of the following is the most likely 1st-line medication in this patient?
options: ['Cyclosporine', 'Infliximab', 'Anakinra', 'Methotrexate', 'High-dose prednisone for 60 days']

male_sentence: A 2-year-old boy is brought in to the office by his parents. They state that their son has recently been more irritable than usual, and he occasionally becomes pale and blue. His parents note that he was diagnosed with a heart murmur, but it was never treated. Physical examination reveals a small child in distress. He is laying on the examination table with his knees drawn to his chest. Cardiac auscultation reveals a harsh, systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the upper left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
female_sentence: A 2-year-old girl is brought in to the office by her parents. They state that their daughter has recently been more irritable than usual, and she occasionally becomes pale and blue. Her parents note that she was diagnosed with a heart murmur, but it was never treated. Physical examination reveals a small child in distress. options: ['Tetralogy of Fallot', 'Transposition of great vessels', 'Pulmonary hypoplasia', 'Atrial septal defect', 'Patent ductus arteriosus']

male_sentence: An 18-year-old male is brought in by fire rescue. The patient was an unrestrained passenger in a motor vehicle crash and was ejected from the vehicle after collision. Upon arrival to the trauma bay, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 6. He is rapidly intubated, and vitals are a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse of 130 bpm, and blood pressure of 83/64 mmHg. He is noted to have multiple ecchymoses over his body, as well as petechiae and purpura. He has a laceration over his clavicle that continues to bleed despite a pressure bandage. Radiographs of his lower extremity show multiple long bone fractures. Two large bore IV lines are placed, and the patient oozes from around the sites of venepuncture. Labs are notable for a WBC of 20,000/mm^3, Hb of 10.1g/dL, platelets of 48,000/mm^3, and prolongation of the PT and aPTT. This patient's presentation can best be explained by which of the following diagnoses?
female_sentence: An 18-year-old female is brought in by fire rescue. The patient was an unrestrained passenger in a motor vehicle crash and was ejected from the vehicle after collision. Upon arrival to the trauma bay, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 6. She is rapidly intubated, and vitals are a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse of 130 bpm, and blood pressure of 83/64 mmHg. This patient's presentation can best be explained by which of the following diagnoses?
options: ['Fat embolization', 'Air embolization', 'Tension pneumothorax', 'Disseminated intravascular coagulation', 'Coagulopathy of trauma']

male_sentence: A 31-year-old man with a history of schizophrenia is brought to the emergency department by police after being found agitated and attempting to steal from a grocery store. His past medical history is only notable for a recent office note from his primary care doctor for treatment of seasonal allergies. His temperature is 101°F (38.3°C), blood pressure is 173/97 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a man who is very irritable and restless. He is not cooperative with exam or history and becomes combative requiring intramuscular medications and security restraining him. After this event, the rest of his exam is notable for 7 mm pupils which are equal and reactive to light, spontaneous movement of all limbs, normal sensation, and warm and sweaty skin. The patient is answering questions and states he wants to kill himself. Which of the following substances was most likely used by this patient?
female_sentence: A 31-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia is brought to the emergency department by police after being found agitated and attempting to steal from a grocery store. Her past medical history is only notable for a recent office note from her primary care doctor for treatment of seasonal allergies. After this event, the rest of her exam is notable for 7 mm pupils which are equal and reactive to light, spontaneous movement of all limbs, normal sensation, and warm and sweaty skin. The patient is answering questions and states she wants to kill herself. Which of the following substances was most likely used by this patient?
options: ['Alcohol', 'Cocaine', 'Diphenhydramine', 'Haloperidol', 'Marijuana']

male_sentence: A 70-year-old man presents with cough and progressively worsening shortness of breath for the last 6 months. He feels short of breath even without exertion and states he ‘got winded’ while walking to his bedroom last night. He describes his cough as non-productive and says he can identify no recognizable triggers. No significant past medical history. The patient is a retired welder and has been living with his son since his wife passed away 5 years ago. He denies any smoking history or current alcohol or drug use. His vital signs include: pulse rate 72/min, respiratory rate 15/min, blood pressure 134/80 mm Hg, and temperature 36.8°C (98.0°F). On physical examination, digital clubbing is noted. Bilateral basilar fine crackles on noted on pulmonary auscultation. Expiratory flow rates are measured and found to be high when corrected for lung volume. A chest X-ray is performed and shown in the image below. Which of the following most likely accounts for the increased expiratory flow rate in this patient?
female_sentence: A 70-year-old woman presents with cough and progressively worsening shortness of breath for the last 6 months. She feels short of breath even without exertion and states she ‘got winded’ while walking to her bedroom last night. She describes her cough as non-productive and says she can identify no recognizable triggers. No significant past medical history. The patient is a retired welder and has been living with her daughter since her husband passed away 5 years ago. She denies any smoking history or current alcohol or drug use. options: ['Anatomical dead space', 'Lung compliance', 'Physiological dead space', 'Radial traction on airway wall', 'Small airway wall thickness']

male_sentence: A 64-year-old man presents with severe respiratory distress. This has onset over the past 3 weeks, progressively worsening. Past history involves congestive heart failure (CHF). Due to concerns of concurrent pneumonia, sputum studies are ordered. Microscopic examination of his sputum demonstrates heart failure cells (hemosiderin-containing macrophages). Which of the following cellular organelles is significant in the formation of these cells?
female_sentence: A 64-year-old woman presents with severe respiratory distress. This has onset over the past 3 weeks, progressively worsening. Past history involves congestive heart failure (CHF). Due to concerns of concurrent pneumonia, sputum studies are ordered. Microscopic examination of her sputum demonstrates heart failure cells (hemosiderin-containing macrophages). Which of the following cellular organelles is significant in the formation of these cells?
options: ['Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)', 'Ribosomes', 'Lysosomes', 'Golgi apparatus', 'Mitochondria']

male_sentence: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath that developed after a 10-hour international flight. His pulse is 124/min and pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. He weighs 50-kg (110-lb). A diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is suspected and intravenous heparin is initiated. If the volume of distribution of heparin is equivalent to 60 mL/kg and the target peak plasma concentration is 0.5 units/mL, which of the following is the most appropriate loading dose for this patient?
female_sentence: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath that developed after a 10-hour international flight. Her pulse is 124/min and pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. She weighs 50-kg (110-lb). A diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is suspected and intravenous heparin is initiated. If the volume of distribution of heparin is equivalent to 60 mL/kg and the target peak plasma concentration is 0.5 units/mL, which of the following is the most appropriate loading dose for this patient?
options: ['3,000 units', '1,500 units', '6,000 units', 'Cannot be calculated, as bioavailability is not known', '30 units']

male_sentence: A 3466-g (7-lb, 10-oz) male newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old man, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8, at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The father has a history of schizophrenia and was treated with lithium until 5 weeks' gestation, when he found out that he was pregnant. The father was treated for alcohol abuse disorder 2 years ago. He has been sober for 14 months now. Examination shows that the child has micrognathia, a broad nasal bridge, a short philtrum, and small, low-set ears. Examination of the mouth shows a cleft palate. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur can be heard over the left sternal border. Echocardiography shows a single overriding great vessel arising from the heart. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?

A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur can be heard over the left sternal border. Echocardiography shows a single overriding great vessel arising from the heart. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
options: ['Low levels of parathyroid hormone in serum', 'Double bubble sign on abdominal x-ray', 'Chromosome 5p deletion on FISH studies', 'Elongated tricuspid valve leaflets on echocardiography', 'Bilateral cataracts on ocular examination']

male_sentence: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department after losing consciousness at work. On presentation, he is found to be somnolent though he is able to be woken by vocal stimuli. He says that over the last 12 hours, he has been experiencing muscle spasms, blurred vision, dry mouth, and hallucinations. He says that the symptoms started after he went on a hike in the woods and foraged from plants along the way. Physical exam reveals dry red skin and enlarged pupils. His bladder is also found to be completely full though he says he is unable to urinate. Which of the following drugs would most likely be administered to this patient to treat his symptoms?
female_sentence: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department after losing consciousness at work. options: ['Atropine', 'Physostigmine', 'Pralidoxime', 'Pyridostigmine', 'Neostigmine']

male_sentence: A 34-year-old man presents to the plastic surgery office 3 months following a rhinoplasty procedure. The patient has been recovering well. However, he has noticed a small whistling noise when he respires through his nose, which you appreciate on physical exam. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this phenomenon?
female_sentence: A 34-year-old woman presents to the plastic surgery office 3 months following a rhinoplasty procedure. The patient has been recovering well. However, she has noticed a small whistling noise when she respires through her nose, which you appreciate on physical exam. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this phenomenon?
options: ['Post-operative swelling', 'A septal hematoma causing a perforation', 'A deviated septum that is now straight, resulting in altered nasal airflow', 'Excessive columellar show resulting in increased nasal airflow', 'A fracture of the bony septum']

male_sentence: A 43-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of rash on the trunk and lower extremities. Three days ago, he visited a spa resort with multiple swimming pools and whirlpools. A friend of his who also visited the spa has developed a similar rash. He does not smoke or drink alcohol and takes no medications. He appears well. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple erythematous, excoriated papules and pustules over the trunk and upper thighs. The inflammation seen in this patient's condition most likely originated in which of the following parts of the skin?
female_sentence: A 43-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of rash on the trunk and lower extremities. options: ['Superfical epidermis', 'Hair follicles', 'Sebaceous glands', 'Papillary dermis', 'Eccrine sweat glands']

male_sentence: A 25-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room after a suicide attempt. His father states that he found a large empty pill bottle next to him. The patient is conscious and tearful. He is currently complaining of severe abdominal pain but refuses to give any other history. He has a blood pressure of 135/86, respiratory rate of 18/min, and heart rate of 86/min. On examination, his abdomen is exquisitely tender with evidence of crepitus in the epigastric region. Abdominal CT reveals a gastric perforation. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
female_sentence: A 25-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room after a suicide attempt. Her mother states that she found a large empty pill bottle next to her. The patient is conscious and tearful. She is currently complaining of severe abdominal pain but refuses to give any other history. Abdominal CT reveals a gastric perforation. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
options: ['Decreased production of PGE2', 'Buildup of a toxic metabolite due to kidney disease', 'Increased stimulation of the vagus nerve', 'Direct irritation of the stomach lining causing inflammation', 'Hypovolemia']

male_sentence: A 3-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for evaluation because his parents have been concerned by a number of troubling signs. Specifically, they have noticed that he has been exhibiting aggressive behavior as well as hyperactivity. In addition, he has had intellectual disability and is slow to hit developmental milestones. Physical exam reveals coarse facies, short stature, and joint stiffness. Eye exam reveals no abnormalities of the cornea or lens. male_sentence: A 21-year-old man with a past medical history significant for Down syndrome presents to the outpatient primary care clinic for a routine follow up and high risk screening. He is relatively high functioning and currently has no additional significant medical conditions. He feels well and a physical examination shows that he is within normal limits. male_sentence: A 4-year-old boy presents to the pediatrician’s office. His mother complains that he has been sleeping poorly, and she has noticed that he often scratches his perianal area. male_sentence: A 69-year-old right-handed man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. On questioning, he has had some difficulty speaking for 3 months. During a conversation, he often has difficulty repeating what his interlocutor has said. He has hypertension and takes hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits. When asked to say the word “kindergarten,” he replies with, “Sintelmarvin… no, that's wrong…kinterflargin, no that isn't it either...kantolargen...no? How about, kindergarten?” The most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is occlusion of a branch of which of the following arteries?
